leviathan4@gibson:~/.trash$ ./bin
01000101 01001011 01001011 01101100 01010100 01000110 00110001 01011000
01110001 01110011 00001010
leviathan4@gibson:~/.trash$ ./bin  | xxd
00000000: 3031 3030 3031 3031 2030 3130 3031 3031  01000101 0100101
00000010: 3120 3031 3030 3130 3131 2030 3131 3031  1 01001011 01101
00000020: 3130 3020 3031 3031 3031 3030 2030 3130  100 01010100 010
00000030: 3030 3131 3020 3030 3131 3030 3031 2030  00110 00110001 0
00000040: 3130 3131 3030 3020 3031 3131 3030 3031  1011000 01110001
00000050: 2030 3131 3130 3031 3120 3030 3030 3130   01110011 000010
00000060: 3130 200a                                10 .
leviathan4@gibson:~/.trash$ ./bin  | xxd -p

303131303020303130313031303020303130303031313020303031313030
303120303130313130303020303131313030303120303131313030313120

leviathan4@gibson:~/.trash$ ./bin  | xxd -p -r
leviathan4@gibson:~/.trash$ python3
Python 3.10.12 (main, Jun 11 2023, 05:26:28) [GCC 11.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> binary_string = '01000101 01001011 01001011 01101100 01010100 01000110
>>> 00110001 01011000 01110001 01110011 00001010'
>>> list = bin
bin(           binary_string
>>> list = binary_string.split()
>>> list
['01000101', '01001011', '01001011', '01101100', '01010100', '01000110',
'00110001', '01011000', '01110001', '01110011', '00001010']
>>> ascii_chars = ''.join([car(int(binary,2)) for binary in list])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <listcomp>
NameError: name 'car' is not defined. Did you mean: 'chr'?
>>> ascii_chars = ''.join([chr(int(binary,2)) for binary in list])
>>> ascii
<built-in function ascii>
>>> ascii_chars
'EKKlTF1Xqs\n'
